properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Slippery road conditions are expected. A low pressure system over New England will give flurries at times heavy tonight. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm locally are expected. These conditions could cause rapidly deteriorating driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T13:59:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T03:59:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0943163624.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A Pacific front will move into the Peace River region early Friday morning. This will be followed by an Arctic front pushing through the region in the afternoon and then stalling on Saturday. Long periods of snow at times mixed with rain are expected with total accumulation of 20 to 30 cm possible by Saturday evening. Snow over the Williston region will change to rain or snow mixed with rain tonight as the warm Pacific front approaches. Rain mixed with snow is expected to develop tonight over the southern Peace River region then change to snow Friday when the Arctic front pushes through. The northern Peace River region will likely stay north of the warm front and receive the highest amount of snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T15:47:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T23:48:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3456493954.2019
Area: Williston, B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry conditions expected across the Island Friday afternoon and Friday night. A low pressure system is currently giving periods of rain across the province. Much colder air will begin moving in from the north Friday morning with periods of snow developing near noon in the west and in the afternoon in the east. Accumulations of up to 5 centimetres are possible by Saturday morning. As this will be the first significant snowfall across much of the province, the travelling public are urged to use caution and prepare for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T16:03:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T00:04:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2336998531.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A series of low pressure systems moving in from the Pacific will bring heavy snow to portions of northwestern Alberta beginning Friday and continuing through the weekend. Total snowfall accumulations may reach 30 to 40 cm. The first system will develop overnight tonight and into Friday morning which will initially bring some rain with a risk of freezing rain. Cold arctic air will then move into the province Friday afternoon, as the next low develops over the Peace Region of Alberta, changing the precipitation over to snow. Snow is then expected to continue through the overnight period on Friday and will finally begin to taper off Sunday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T14:30:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T22:31:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0304704751.2019

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls tonight and Friday. Snow squalls have developed off Lake Huron and will continue through Friday afternoon. The most intense bands are expected tonight with conditions slowly improving through the day Friday. Strong winds may accompany these bands resulting in blowing snow at times. Local snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm will be possible by Friday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T19:23:55-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wintry weather expected for parts of Nova Scotia Friday night into Saturday. A low pressure system will bring rain to the province tonight and Friday. Colder air will move in behind this system on Friday. As this colder air arrives from the northwest, showers will turn to periods of snow Friday afternoon or evening. Snowfall amounts of 2 to 4 centimetres are possible for most of the province in the northerly onshore flow, with the highest amounts expected over northern Nova Scotia, where total amounts could reach near 15 centimetres by Saturday morning. As this will be the first significant snowfall across parts of the province, the travelling public are urged to use caution and prepare for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T15:57:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-07T23:58:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2305976557.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A Pacific front will move into the northern Peace River region early Friday morning. This will be followed by an Arctic front pushing through the region during the day Friday and then stalling on Saturday. As a result, long periods of snow heavy at times are expected in the region with total accumulation of 20 to 30 cm by Saturday evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T22:22:18-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T06:23:18-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3186171871.2019
Area: B.C. North Peace River
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight and Friday. Flurries and local snow squalls have developed off Georgian Bay and Lake Huron and are expected to continue intermittently through Friday afternoon. While the heaviest snow squalls are expected to remain south and east of the Bruce Peninsula, portions of the Peninsula can expect locally heavy snow and reduced visibilities at times making travel difficult. Motorists are advised to watch for quickly changing weather conditions and adjust their driving accordingly. Local snowfall accumulations of 5 to 15 cm will be possible. If the snow squalls look to be more intense or persistent than currently forecast, a snow squall warning may be required for the area. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T19:16:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T03:17:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0868378710.2019
Area: Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls continue today. Local snow squalls will continue today. Strong winds may accompany these bands resulting in blowing snow at times. The worst conditions are expected to remain west of the city of Barrie and Highway 400. Local snowfall accumulations of 30 to 40 cm will be possible under the most intense bands by the time the snow squalls weaken later today. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and poor driving conditions expected. Total snowfall: near 15 cm except locally up to 25 cm over higher terrain. Locations: Corner Brook and vicinity, Gros Morne, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Green Bay - White Bay, west of Grand Falls-Windsor and Buchans. Time span: today. Remarks: Snowfall accumulations are likely to vary considerably with the highest amounts expected from Badger to Buchans, northern sections of the Burgeo highway, Green Bay - White Bay and higher elevations between Deer Lake and Corner Brook and Deer Lake and Gros Morne. Areas near the coast and in lower lying areas through the Humber Valley are likely to see much lower amounts. The snow will taper off this evening but flurries, snow squalls, and strong westerly winds will develop again early Saturday along the west coast and persist through Saturday night. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-09T00:55:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T08:56:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3643745086.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea, Corner Brook and vicinity, Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Gros Morne, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Intense snow squalls tonight through Friday. Snow squalls have developed off southern Lake Huron. These snow squalls will be capable of producing local accumulations up to 25 cm by Friday morning. Visibilities will be significantly reduced at times due to the heavy snow. Occasional lightning and thunder may accompany these snow squalls tonight as well. Additional snowfall accumulations in the 10 to 15 cm range will be possible during the day Friday bringing total snowfall accumulations to 30 to 40 cm locally. The snow squalls are forecast to weaken by Friday evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T19:30:23-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T03:31:23-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1536643910.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow expected for much of New Brunswick tonight and/or Friday. A low pressure system is currently giving snow to much of New Brunswick. Over portions of southern areas, rain is occurring but will change to snow overnight. Periods of snow will redevelop or persist mainly over eastern and southern parts of the province on Friday before easing off later in the day. Snowfall amounts across the province will range between 2 and 10 centimetres, with the highest amounts expected over eastern sections on Friday, where locally total amounts could reach near 15 centimetres over higher terrain. As this will be the first significant snowfall across much of the province, the travelling public are urged to use caution and prepare for winter driving conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T17:29:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T01:30:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1492112831.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A Pacific front is moving across the northern interior tonight. Snow at times heavy had begun this evening over Williston with an additional 5 to 10 cm in the forecast. Snow will change to rain or becoming mixed with rain overnight as the the airmass warms up. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Snow squall warnings are issued when bands of snow form that produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. Freezing rain is expected to form in the Slave Lake, Athabasca, Barrhead, and Fort Saskatchewan regions overnight and will move southeastward along the Yellowhead Highway to Lloydminster by Friday morning. Freezing rain has also formed in the Peace River region, and is expected to end by Friday morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T13:59:22-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A Pacific frontal system will move into the northern BC interior Friday morning. This system will be followed by an Arctic front pushing through the region Friday afternoon and then stalling over the region on Saturday. Long periods of snow are expected with total snowfall amounts of 30 to 40 cm forecast by Saturday evening. The heaviest snowfall is expected on Friday night and Saturday. Gusty winds behind the Arctic front may also give reduced visibilities in blowing snow starting Friday night. The snow will taper to flurries on Saturday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T22:23:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T06:24:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3673517168.2019
Area: Highway 97 - Pine Pass
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A slow moving Pacific frontal system will continue to give rain to the North Coast. Rain over the inland sections near Stewart will become heavier tomorrow morning and will persist through tomorrow night. The rain is expected to taper to a few showers on Saturday morning as the front finally moves away from the region. Total rainfall amounts of 70 to 100 mm can be expected within a 48 hour period. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T21:22:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T05:23:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4005113430.2019
Area: North Coast - inland including Stewart
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow, and snow will rapidly accumulate. On Friday afternoon, cold arctic air moving over Great Slave Lake will create favourable conditions for snow squalls to develop. Snow squalls are likely to persist until Saturday morning. Local snowfall accumulations of 20 to 30 cm are possible. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T21:00:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T05:01:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3558730978.2019
Area: Ft. Resolution Region including Hwy. 6
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Intense snow squalls tonight through Friday. These snow squalls will be capable of producing significant snowfall accumulations tonight with local amounts up to 25 cm possible by Friday morning. Strong winds will accompany these snow squalls resulting in blowing snow and significantly reduced visibilities at times. Conditions will slowly improve through the day Friday, though additional significant snowfall accumulations will be possible. Occasional lightning and thunder may accompany these snow squalls. Total snowfall accumulations of 30 to 40 cm locally will be possible by time the snow squalls weaken Friday evening. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-08T19:25:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T03:26:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2699874419.2019
Area: Goderich - Bluewater - Southern Huron County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Total rainfall: 45 to 65 mm. Locations: Burgeo - Ramea. Time span: today. Remarks: Inland and higher terrain areas of the Burgeo highway, particularly northern sections, can expect accumulating snow today with locally 10 cm possible. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-09T00:50:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-08T08:51:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1313119847.2019
Area: Burgeo - Ramea
properties.Author: Environment Canada
